snippet: Sugar makers have historically relied solely on the weather to predict good and bad syrup years. But research suggests that seed production is a key indicator of what is set to flow from the trees and onto your pancakes.
abstract: Scientists are predicting that trees in Northeastern United States and Quebec Province, Canada, are likely to undergo mast year--time when perennial trees like maples synchronize their seed cycles and flower as one; mast years are associated with low seed counts, which are in turn associated with increase in tree sap and boon for maple syrup producers.
lead_paragraph: Sugar makers have historically relied solely on the weather to predict good and bad syrup years. But research suggests that seed production is a key indicator of what is set to flow from the trees and onto your pancakes.

headline.main: The Bloom Is On for Maple Syrup
headline.print_headline: The Bloom Is On for Maple Syrup
